metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. Landlords (Civil Appeals Nos. 53 to 81, 133 to 137, 253 to 263 of 1960)
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 53 to 81, 133 to 137, 253 to 263 of 1960

facts.text: Government of Bihar issued circular letter dated 19th April 1948 to District Officers directing execution of 100 minor irrigation works per district under sections 5, 5A, 32A and 32B of the Bihar Private Irrigation Works Act, 1922, financed initially by Government with 50% recovery from beneficiaries.
Officials of Revenue Department submitted reports to Sub-Divisional Officers (vested with Collector's powers under s.5A) stating irrigation works needed repairs.

Sub-Divisional Officers passed orders under s.5A using cyclostyled forms, reciting necessity of repair and opinion that delay from s.3 notice would adversely affect lands, ordering immediate execution without recording reasons; in some cases, name of work not even filled.
Public notice issued under s.5A(1) proviso that work had begun, works completed.
Cost of works apportioned under ss.7 and 8, landlords' share fixed at 50% of total cost as per government circular.
Demands issued under s.11 for landlords' share as public demand under s.12; by this time, landlords' estates taken over under Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950.
Landlords filed writ petitions under Art.226 in Patna High Court challenging legality of demands, alleging s.5A orders invalid for lack of recorded reasons.
Patna High Court allowed writs on grounds: (1) Collectors mechanically reproduced s.5A terms without applying mind; (2) failure to record reasons under s.5A rendered action void.
State granted special leave to appeal to Supreme Court; appeals heard together on common point of s.5A construction.

legal_issues.text: Proper construction of s.5A of Bihar Private Irrigation Works Act, 1922: whether requirement that Collector record reasons for opinion that delay from s.3 proceedings would adversely affect lands is mandatory, or directory.
Whether s.5A orders are administrative or quasi-judicial, and if failure to record reasons renders orders void.
Whether prior reports of overseers/estimating officers can substitute for Collector's recorded reasons under s.5A.
High Court's jurisdiction under Art.226 to quash demands based on invalid s.5A orders passed before Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.5A vests administrative jurisdiction in Collector based on subjective satisfaction of emergency; recording reasons is directory, not mandatory; analogy to Art.320(3) Constitution in State of UP v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.5A Bihar Private Irrigation Works Act, 1922; State of Uttar Pradesh v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava (1958 SCR 533)

petitioner_arguments.text: Collectors had before them reports of overseers/estimating officers recommending s.5A action, which provide reasons; these reports and orders should be read together.
High Court lacked jurisdiction under Art.226 as s.5A orders administrative, not quasi-judicial; some orders pre-Constitution.
Respondents acquiesced by not objecting immediately or approaching Board of Revenue under s.46; benefited from repairs.
Remedy under s.5B for any loss sustained.

respondent_arguments.text: s.5A orders invalid as Collectors failed to record reasons as required; mechanical reproduction of section terms shows no application of mind.
s.5A departs from normal quasi-judicial procedure under ss.3-5; recording reasons only safeguard against abuse, must be mandatory.

court_reasoning.text: s.5A introduced for emergencies dispensing with ss.3-5 procedure; recording reasons mandatory condition precedent for power, only protection to affected persons; distinguishes from directory Art.320(3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Requirement of recording reasons is mandatory, not directory, based on scheme of Act and purpose to safeguard rights.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming administrative jurisdiction and subjective satisfaction, statute requires reasons recorded; reports of subordinates do not substitute for Collector's own recorded reasons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Orders distinguish conclusion (emergency exists) from reasons why normal procedure cannot be followed.

court_reasoning.text: High Court quashed demands under s.11, not s.5A orders themselves; void orders cannot found liability; demands post-Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to set aside void orders; jurisdiction exists to quash illegal demands.

court_reasoning.text: No acquiescence as s.5A gives no prior notice/opportunity to object; s.5B remedy for third-party losses, not apportioned costs.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.46 alternative remedy discretionary under Art.226.

holdings.text: Requirement under s.5A(1) that Collector record reasons for opinion is mandatory; failure renders order null and void.
Prior reports do not comply with recording requirement; demands based on void s.5A orders illegal.
High Court had jurisdiction to quash post-Constitution demands traceable to pre-Constitution void orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
precedents_cited.relevance: Held Art.320(3) directory; distinguished as s.5A recording reasons is mandatory safeguard in context of depriving hearing.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Private Irrigation Works Act, 1922 (Bihar and Orissa Act 5 of 1922)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs repair of private irrigation works; s.5A allows emergency repairs without notice/enquiry if reasons recorded; failure invalidates orders and subsequent demands.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 (Act 1 of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Estates of landlords taken over by date of demands.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court writ jurisdiction to quash illegal demands; Art.320(3) distinguished.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed State's appeals, upholding Patna High Court orders quashing demands for landlords' share of irrigation repair costs, as s.5A orders void for failure to record mandatory reasons.
outcome.relief_granted: Writs allowed by High Court upheld; demands quashed.

key_quotes.text: "the recording of the reasons is a condition for the emergence of the power to make the order under sub-s.(1)".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds recording reasons mandatory precondition for s.5A power.

key_quotes.text: "If the question whether the circumstances recited in s.5A(1) exist or not is entirely for the Collector to decide in his discretion, it will be seen that the recording of the reasons is the only protection which is afforded to the persons affected".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose: safeguard against arbitrary deprivation of hearing and liability.

key_quotes.text: "the orders of the Collector which did not comply with the statutory condition precedent must be null and void and of no effect altogether."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Consequence of non-compliance: orders void ab initio.
